title: 108_hr5226
content: Crop disaster assistance. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "additional coverage," "insurable commodity," and "noninsurable commodity" related to agricultural commodities and insurance under the Federal Crop Insurance Act. The curr_chunk defines "commodity" as an agricultural commodity eligible for assistance under the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996. The Secretary of Agriculture can provide emergency financial assistance to producers on a farm with qualifying crop losses for the 2003 or 2004 crop year using funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation. The Secretary can provide emergency financial assistance to producers on a farm with qualifying crop losses for the 2003 or 2004 crop year due to damaging weather conditions. Assistance will be administered in the same manner as provided under a previous Act, with specific loss thresholds for quantity and quality losses. Producers on a farm may be ineligible for assistance under this section if they did not obtain insurance for insurable commodities or file paperwork for noninsurable commodities. Producers on a farm may be ineligible for assistance if they did not obtain insurance for insurable commodities or file paperwork for noninsurable commodities by the State deadline. The Secretary may waive this requirement if producers enter into a contract agreeing to obtain insurance for insurable commodities. Producers must agree to obtain insurance for insurable commodities and file paperwork for noninsurable commodities for the next 2 crops under a contract with the Secretary. Producers must agree to obtain insurance for insurable commodities and file paperwork for noninsurable commodities for the next 2 crops under a contract with the Secretary. In case of a violation, the producer must reimburse the Secretary for the full assistance received, and payment limitations apply, not exceeding 95 percent of the crop value. The Secretary may limit payments to producers to 95 percent of the crop value in case of losses, including crop insurance payments or payments for losses under specific acts. The producer's assistance under the Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 may be reduced by the amount received from Florida Disaster Programs for the same loss. The Livestock Assistance Program is outlined in Section 2. Emergency Financial Assistance: The Secretary of Agriculture will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide payments for livestock losses in counties designated as emergencies after January 1, 2003. This includes support for the American Indian livestock program. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide assistance for livestock losses in designated emergency counties, without penalizing producers who take actions to mitigate disaster conditions. The Secretary will not penalize producers who reduce their livestock numbers due to disaster conditions when receiving assistance. The Tree Assistance Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Agriculture will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide emergency assistance to producers who suffered tree losses between December 1, 2003, and December 31, 2004. Additionally, $15,000,000 will be used to provide reimbursement to eligible orchardists under the tree assistance program. The Commodity Credit Corporation will use an additional $15,000,000 to provide reimbursement to eligible forest landowners who suffered tree losses during a specified period. The Secretary of Agriculture will allocate $50,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation for the Emergency Conservation Program, providing assistance to participants with the maximum cost share percentage. Additionally, the Commodity Credit Corporation will be utilized to implement this Act, and regulations will be established accordingly. The Secretary of Agriculture may issue regulations to implement the Act without following certain procedural requirements. The Secretary of Agriculture can issue regulations to implement the Act without following certain procedural requirements, including the Paperwork Reduction Act and using the authority provided under section 808 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 7. OFFSET. Amends Section 1241(a)(3) of the Food Security Act of 1985 to allocate $6,037,000,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2014.
